ABSTRACT. J. Silverman proved that a dynamical system on ð‘ƒÂ¹ descends to the field of moduli if it is polynomial or it has even degree, but for non-polynomial ones of odd degree the picture is less clear. We give a complete characterization of which dynamical systems over ð‘ƒÂ¹ descend to the field of moduli.

We work over a perfect field ð‘˜ with algebraic closure ð¾.

Consider ðœ™ : ð‘ƒÂ¹_ð¾ â†’ ð‘ƒÂ¹_ð¾ a finite map of degree ð‘‘ â‰¥ 2. The interplay between the number-theoretic and dynamical properties of ðœ™ has been the subject of a lot of research in the last decades, see e.g. [Sil07].

The dynamics of ðœ™ do not change if we conjugate it by a projective linear transformation ð‘“ âˆˆ PGLâ‚‚(ð¾). Define ðœ™^ð‘“ â‰ ð‘“â»Â¹ âˆ˜ ðœ™ âˆ˜ ð‘“; this gives an action of PGLâ‚‚(ð¾) on the set of rational functions. A dynamical system Î¾ on ð‘ƒÂ¹_ð¾ is an equivalence class for this action.

The Galois group Gal(ð¾/ð‘˜) acts on the set of dynamical systems by acting on the coefficients of the corresponding rational functions in ð¾(ð‘¡). The field of moduli ð‘˜_Î¾ is the subfield of ð¾ fixed by the elements of Gal(ð¾/ð‘˜) mapping Î¾ to itself. If Î¾ descends to a dynamical system on a subextension ð‘˜' âŠ‚ ð¾, then clearly ð‘˜_Î¾ âŠ‚ ð‘˜'. It is then natural to ask whether Î¾ descends to a dynamical system on ð‘˜_Î¾.

Recall that the stabilizer ð”„_ðœ™ âŠ‚ PGLâ‚‚(ð¾) of ðœ™ is the subgroup {ð‘“ âˆˆ PGLâ‚‚(ð¾) | ðœ™^ð‘“ = ðœ™}; its isomorphism class only depends on Î¾, so that ð”„_Î¾ is well defined as an abstract group, and it is finite [Sil95, Proposition 4.1]. J. Silverman proved the following.

Theorem 1 ([Sil95, Theorem 5.1]). Let Î¾ be a dynamical system on ð‘ƒÂ¹_ð¾, assume that char ð‘˜ does not divide |ð”„_Î¾|. If deg Î¾ is even or if Î¾ contains a polynomial, then Î¾ descends to a dynamical system on ð‘ƒÂ¹_{ð‘˜_Î¾}.

Furthermore, Silverman proved that Î¾ descends to a Brauerâ€“Severi curve if the stabilizer ð”„_Î¾ is trivial [Sil95, Theorem 2.1]. We prove that every dynamical system with non-trivial stabilizer descends to ð‘ƒÂ¹_{ð‘˜_Î¾}. This is somewhat counter-intuitive, since the case of non-trivial stabilizer is more complex.

We thus get a complete characterization of descent properties for dynamical systems on ð‘ƒÂ¹_ð¾.

R. Hidalgo proved that, in characteristic 0, every dynamical system \( \xi \) descends to a dynamical system on \( \mathbb{P}^1_{k'} \), where \( k'/k_\xi \) is an extension of degree at most 2 [Hid14]. As a consequence of Theorem 2, Hidalgo's theorem holds in any characteristic, since every dynamical system descends to a Brauerâ€“Severi curve over \( k_\xi \) and every Brauerâ€“Severi curve is split by an extension of degree at most 2.

Theorem 2 implies the following generalization of Silverman's result.

**Theorem 3.** *A dynamical system* \( \xi = [\varphi] \) *on* \( \mathbb{P}^1_K \) *descends to a dynamical system on* \( \mathbb{P}^1_{k_\xi} \) *if any of the following conditions holds.*

- The stabilizer \( A_\xi \) is non-trivial.
- The degree \( d \) is even.
- There exists an integer \( e \geq 2 \) such that the number of points with ramification index \( e \) is odd.

If \( \xi \) contains a polynomial, either \( \xi \) contains \( x^d \) (which is clearly defined over the field of moduli) or there is a unique \( K \)-point with ramification index \( d \), so that \( \xi \) satisfies the third condition of Theorem 3.

We mention that analogous problems for dynamical systems on \( \mathbb{P}^n \) are studied in [HM14, DS19, Breb]. Furthermore, recently F. Veneziano and S. Vishkautsan have studied similar problems for iterates of a dynamical system on \( \mathbb{P}^1 \) [VV24].

**A remark about Silverman's results.** Silverman does not assume the base field to be perfect, so our results seem to be less general in this regard. However, if we drop this hypothesis there is a technical flaw in Silverman's paper. Let \( k \) be an arbitrary field, \( \overline{K} \) an algebraic closure, \( K \subset \overline{K} \) the separable closure, \( k^p \subset \overline{K} \) the perfect closure. There is a natural identification of Galois groups \( \mathrm{Gal}(K/k) = \mathrm{Gal}(\overline{K}/k^p) \), call them \( G_k \).

In [Sil95, Proposition 1.2], it is stated that \( H^1(G_k, \mathrm{PGL}_2(\overline{K})) \) classifies Brauerâ€“Severi curves over \( k \). However, the proof uses a reference [Sil09, Â§X, Theorem 2.2] which assumes the base field to be perfect. In general, Brauerâ€“Severi curves over \( k \) are classified by \( H^1(G_k, \mathrm{PGL}_2(K)) \) [GS17, Theorem 5.2.1], while \( H^1(G_k, \mathrm{PGL}_2(\overline{K})) \) classifies Brauerâ€“Severi curves over \( k^p \).

If \( \mathrm{char}\, k \neq 2 \), the natural map

\[
H^1(G_k, \mathrm{PGL}_2(K)) = \operatorname{Br}(k)[2] \to H^1(G_k, \mathrm{PGL}_2(\overline{K})) = \operatorname{Br}(k^p)[2]
\]

is an isomorphism, since \( \operatorname{Br}(k) \to \operatorname{Br}(k^p) \) is surjective [Jac96, Theorem 4.1.5] with char \( k \)-primary kernel. Still, Silverman's article remains flawed even if we assume \( \mathrm{char}\, k \neq 2 \). In fact, in the proof of [Sil95, Theorem 2.1(b)], the morphism \( \Phi = j g \varphi g^{-1} j^{-1} \) is defined over \( \overline{K} \) (because \( g \) is defined over \( \overline{k} \)) as opposed to \( K \): in order to verify that \( \Phi \) is defined over \( k \), Silverman checks that \( \Phi \) is Galois-invariant, but since \( \Phi \) is a priori defined over \( \overline{K} \) this only proves that \( \Phi \) is defined over \( k^p \).

Finally, let us mention that there is a way to study the problem even when the base field is not perfect. This is done by replacing Galois cohomology either with fppf cohomology or stack theory, such as in [BV24]. We don't know whether all the various results remain completely true in this generality. Still, most of their content remains true, see Â§4.

Acknowledgements. I would like to thank J. Silverman, A. Vistoli and F. Veneziano for very fruitful discussions.

The restriction of \(\varphi : \mathcal{P}^D_\xi \to \mathcal{P}^D_\xi\) to the tautological section \(\text{Spec } K \to \mathcal{G}^D_\xi = [\text{Spec } K / \mathcal{N}_\phi]\) identifies canonically with \(\phi : \mathbb{P}^1_K \to \mathbb{P}^1_K\). Since \(\mathcal{G}^D_\xi\) is a gerbe over \(k_\xi\), given any section \(s : \text{Spec } k_\xi \to \mathcal{G}^D_\xi\) the base change \(s_K\) is isomorphic to the tautological section and hence the restriction \(\varphi|_s : \mathcal{P}^D_{\xi, s} \to \mathcal{P}^D_{\xi, s}\) is a model of \(\phi\) over \(k_\xi\).

On the other hand, if \(b : B \to B\) is a model of \(\phi\) over \(k_\xi\), the natural Galois action on \(B_K \cong \mathbb{P}^1_K\) defines a section \(\text{Gal}(K/k_\xi) \to \mathcal{N}_\xi\), which in turn induces a section \(s : \text{Spec } k_\xi \to \mathcal{G}^D_\xi\) by [Brea, Lemma 5]. It is straightforward to check that these constructions are inverses to each other; we have thus proved the following.

**Lemma 5.** The dynamical system \(\xi\) descends to a Brauerâ€“Severi curve over \(k_\xi\) if and only if \(\mathcal{G}^D_\xi(k_\xi) \neq \emptyset\). Furthermore, it descends to a dynamical system on \(\mathbb{P}^1_{k_\xi}\) if and only if \(\mathcal{P}^D_\xi(k_\xi) \neq \emptyset\). \(\Box\)

If \(k_\xi\) is finite, then \(\mathcal{G}^D_\xi(k_\xi) \neq \emptyset\) by [Bre24, Lemma 13]. Since Brauerâ€“Severi curves over finite fields always have rational points [GS17, Remark 5.1.6], then \(\xi\) is defined over \(\mathbb{P}^1_{k_\xi}\) by Lemma 5. From now on, we assume that \(k_\xi\) is infinite.

Let \(\mathcal{P}^D_\xi \to \mathbb{P}^D_\xi\) be the coarse moduli space of \(\mathcal{P}^D_\xi\), it is a Brauerâ€“Severi curve over \(k_\xi\) with a natural identification \(\mathbb{P}^D_{\xi, K} \cong \mathbb{P}^1_K / \mathcal{A}_\phi \cong \mathbb{P}^1_K\). Since the action of \(\mathcal{A}_\phi\) on \(\mathbb{P}^1_K\) is faithful, the stack \(\mathcal{P}^D_\xi\) is generically a scheme, thus we have a birational inverse \(\mathbb{P}^D_\xi \dashrightarrow \mathcal{P}^D_\xi\). Since we are assuming that \(k_\xi\) is infinite, we get the following corollary of Lemma 5.

**Corollary 6.** The dynamical system \(\xi\) descends to a dynamical system on \(\mathbb{P}^1_{k_\xi}\) if and only if \(\mathbb{P}^D_\xi(k_\xi) \neq \emptyset\).

By [Sil95, Theorem 2.1], it is enough to prove that \(\xi\) descends to \(\mathbb{P}^1_{k_\xi}\) if the stabilizer \(\mathcal{A}_\xi\) is non-trivial.

So let us assume that \(\mathcal{A}_\xi\) is non-trivial; equivalently, \(\mathcal{G}^D_\xi \neq \text{Spec } k_\xi\). Assume by contradiction that \(\xi\) does not descend to \(\mathbb{P}^1_{k_\xi}\); by Corollary 6, this is equivalent to assuming that \(\mathbb{P}^D_\xi(k_\xi) = \emptyset\).

The composition \(\mathbb{P}^D_\xi \dashrightarrow \mathcal{P}^D_\xi \to \mathcal{G}^D_\xi\) defines a morphism whose geometric fibers are irreducible curves of genus 0. In fact, if \(\text{Spec } K \to \mathcal{G}^D_\xi = [\text{Spec } K / \mathcal{N}_\xi]\) is the preferred section and we base change to \(K\), we have a commutative diagram

which is cartesian on the locus of points where the action is free. Since \( \mathbf{P}^D_\xi(k_\xi) = \emptyset \), by [Bre24, Proposition 28] we get that \( \mathcal{A}_\phi \) is cyclic of order prime with char \( k \).

Choose coordinates on \( \mathbf{P}^1_K \) so that \( 0, \infty \) are the two fixed points for the action of \( \mathcal{A}_\xi \). Let \( n \) be the order of \( \mathcal{A}_\phi \), then \( \mathcal{A}_\xi \) acts on \( \mathbf{P}^1_K \) by \( x \mapsto \zeta_n x \), where \( \zeta_n \) is a primitive \( n \)-th root of 1. The fact that \( \mathcal{A}_\phi \) stabilizes \( \phi \) implies that \( \phi \) has the form

\[
\phi(x) = \lambda x^{a} \prod_{i=0}^{n-1} \frac{q_1(\zeta_n^i x)}{q_2(\zeta_n^i x)}
\]

for some \( \lambda \in K \), \( a \in \mathbb{Z} \) and \( q_1, q_2 \in K[x] \).

Notice that, since \( x \mapsto \zeta_n x \) stabilizes \( \phi \), we get the equation \( \phi(\zeta_n x) = \zeta_n \phi(x) \). Applying this to the formula above, we get

\[
\zeta_n = \zeta_n^a,
\]

i.e. \( a \equiv 1 \pmod{n} \).

Let us now prove that

\[
2a + n \deg q_1 - n \deg q_2 = 0.
\]

Equivalently, we want to prove that the orders of vanishing of \( \phi \) on \( 0 \) and \( \infty \) are equal.

Notice that the subset \( \{0, \infty\} \subset \mathbf{P}^1_K \) is distinguished in the sense of [Bre23, Â§7]: if \( h \in \mathcal{N}_\phi \) and \( g \in \mathcal{A}_\phi \), then \( g(h(0)) = h(h^{-1} g h(0)) = h(0) \) and hence \( h(0) \) is a fixed point for \( \mathcal{A}_\phi \). If the orders of vanishing of \( \phi \) on \( 0 \) and \( \infty \) are different, then \( \{0\} \) is a distinguished subset as well, hence by [Bre23, Lemma 17] the image of \( 0 \) in \( \mathbf{P}^1_K/\mathcal{A}_\xi \) descends to a \( k_\xi \)-rational point of \( \mathbf{P}^D_\xi \), which is absurd.

Recall that we are assuming that \( \mathcal{A}_\phi \) is non-trivial, or equivalently \( n \neq 1 \). Since \( a \equiv 1 \pmod{n} \) and \( 2a + n\deg q_1 - n\deg q_2 = 0 \), the only possibility is \( n = 2 \). Hence, we get the equality \( a = \deg q_2 - \deg q_1 \) and the formula

\[
\phi(x) = \lambda x^{\deg q_2 - \deg q_1} \frac{q_1(x)q_1(-x)}{q_2(x)q_2(-x)}.
\]

This implies that \( \phi \) has degree equal to \( 2 \max(\deg q_1, \deg q_2) \). By Silverman's theorem, this implies that \( \phi \) descends to \( \mathbf{P}^1_{k_\xi} \), giving the desired contradiction.

The fact that \( \xi \) descends to \( \mathbf{P}^1_K \) under the first condition is a particular case of Theorem 2. If the second condition holds, then this follows by Theorem 2 plus the well-known fact that a finite morphism \( B \to B \) has odd degree if \( B \) is a non-trivial Brauerâ€“Severi curve; Silverman gives a proof of this fact in [Sil95, Corollary 2.2].

We conclude that $\mathbb{P}^D_\xi(k_\xi) \neq \emptyset$ by [Bre24, Lemma 27].

Let $k$ be any field with algebraic closure $\bar{K}$, separable closure $K \subset \bar{K}$ and perfect closure $k^p \subset \bar{K}$. A dynamical system is an equivalence class for the action of $\text{PGL}_2(\bar{K})$ on the set of finite morphisms $\mathbb{P}^1_{\bar{K}} \to \mathbb{P}^1_{\bar{K}}$. Fix $\xi$ a dynamical system of degree $d \geq 2$. We have already seen in Â§1 that if the base field is finite then dynamical systems always descend to the field of moduli. We may then assume that $k$ is infinite.

**Definition 7.** Define categories fibered in groupoids $\mathcal{G}_\xi$, $\mathcal{P}_\xi$ as follows.  
If $S$ is a scheme over $k$, then $\mathcal{G}_\xi(S)$ is the groupoid of commutative diagrams
\[
\begin{array}{ccc}
P & \xrightarrow{\psi} & P \\
\downarrow{\pi} & & \downarrow{\pi} \\
S & = & S
\end{array}
\]
where $\pi : P \to S$ is a projective bundle of relative dimension 1 such that, for every geometric point $s \in S$, the restriction $\psi|_s : P_s \to P_s$ is an element of $\xi$.  
We define $\mathcal{P}_\xi(S)$ to be the groupoid of commutative diagrams as above plus a section $S \to P$. There is an obvious induced commutative diagram
\[
\begin{array}{ccc}
P_\xi & \longrightarrow & P_\xi \\
\downarrow & & \downarrow \\
G_\xi & = & G_\xi
\end{array}
\]
Arrows in $\mathcal{G}_\xi(S)$ are isomorphisms $P' \simeq P$ over $S$ commuting with the diagrams. Arrows in $\mathcal{P}_\xi(S)$ are isomorphisms $P' \simeq P$ over $S$ commuting with the diagrams and mapping the section $S \to P'$ to the section $S \to P$.

**Lemma 8.** The fibered categories $\mathcal{G}_\xi$, $\mathcal{P}_\xi$ are fppf stacks locally of finite presentation.

**Proof.** This follows from [Vis05, Theorem 4.38, Example 4.39]. â–¡

Notice that the Galois groups $\text{Gal}(\bar{K}/k^p)$ and $\text{Gal}(K/k)$ naturally coincide, and that they act on the set of dynamical systems by acting on the coefficients of the corresponding functions.

**Definition 9.** Denote by $H \subset \text{Gal}(\bar{K}/k^p) = \text{Gal}(K/k)$ the subgroup of elements $\sigma$ such that $\xi^\sigma = \xi$; it is an open subgroup since $\xi$ contains a function defined over a finite extension of $k$.  
Assume that $\xi$ contains a morphism defined over $K$. The field of moduli of $\xi$ is the fixed field $k_\xi = K^H \subset K$.

**Proposition 10.** Assume that $\xi$ contains a morphism defined over $K$. The stacks $\mathcal{G}_\xi$, $\mathcal{P}_\xi$ are algebraic with finite inertia, and $\mathcal{G}_\xi$ is a finite gerbe over the field of moduli $k_\xi$.

Denote by \(\mathcal{A}_\xi\) the automorphism group scheme of any representative of \(\xi\), its isomorphism class is well defined as an abstract finite group scheme over \(\overline{K}\) (as opposed to the automorphism group of a fixed representative, which has a natural embedding in \(\mathrm{PGL}_2\)).

Notice that \(\mathcal{P}_\xi\) is generically a scheme, since its base change to \(\overline{K}\) is the quotient stack \([\mathbb{P}^1_{\overline{K}} / \mathrm{Aut}_{\overline{K}}(\phi)]\). Furthermore, \(\mathcal{P}_\xi\) is a Brauerâ€“Severi curve over \(k_\xi\), since its base change to \(\overline{K}\) is \(\mathbb{P}^1_{\overline{K}} / \mathrm{Aut}_{\overline{K}}(\phi)\). Since we are assuming that \(k\) is infinite, then \(\mathcal{P}_\xi(k_\xi)\) is non-empty if and only if \(P_\xi(k_\xi)\) is non-empty. The first statement then follows from the definition of \(\mathcal{P}_\xi\).

Furthermore, \(\xi\) descends to a unique Brauerâ€“Severi curve over \(k_\xi\) if the group scheme \(\mathcal{A}_\xi\) is trivial. Finally, \(\xi\) always descends to \(\mathbb{P}^1_{k'}\), where \(k'\) is a finite extension of \(k_\xi\) of degree at most 2.

Lemma 11. The dynamical system \(\xi\) descends to \(\mathbb{P}^1_{k_\xi}\) if and only if \(P_\xi(k_\xi) \neq \emptyset\). It descends to a Brauerâ€“Severi curve over \(k_\xi\) if and only if \(\mathcal{G}_\xi(k_\xi) \neq \emptyset\).
